title: Interfaces (The Contract)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine a job posting: 'Looking for employee who can: Drive, Operate forklift, Read inventory systems.' This is a CONTRACT - if you want the job, you MUST have these skills!

An INTERFACE is a contract for classes. It says: 'If you implement me, you MUST provide these methods.' Unlike abstract classes:
• NO implementation (just method signatures)
• A class can implement MULTIPLE interfaces (but only inherit from ONE class!)
• All members are public and abstract by default

Naming: Interfaces start with 'I' by convention: IDrawable, IPlayable, IComparable.

Think: IDrawable = 'anything that can be drawn'. Button, Image, Shape all implement IDrawable. They're completely different, but share the ability to be drawn!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Interfaces use 'interface' keyword. By convention, names start with 'I'. Define WHAT, not HOW.
Interface methods have NO body, NO access modifiers (implicitly public). Just signatures ending with semicolon.
Class can implement MULTIPLE interfaces! Separate with commas. Must implement ALL methods from ALL interfaces.
Interface = pure contract (no implementation). Abstract = template with some implementation. Can implement many interfaces, inherit from one class.

challenge.instructions:
Create a media player system with interfaces!

1. INTERFACE 'IPlayable':
   - void Play()
   - void Pause()
   - void Stop()

2. INTERFACE 'IRecordable':
   - void Record()
   - void SaveRecording()

3. CLASS 'VideoPlayer' implements IPlayable
4. CLASS 'AudioRecorder' implements IPlayable AND IRecordable
5. Create objects, call methods polymorphically
challenge.hint: Interface: 'interface IName { void Method(); }'. Implement: 'class C : IName { public void Method() { } }'. Must implement ALL interface methods!
commonStickingPoints: Adding implementation in interface: 'void Method() { code }' in interface is WRONG! Interfaces have NO implementation (except default interface methods in C# 8+, advanced topic).
Forgetting 'public' in implementation: When implementing interface methods in class, you MUST make them 'public'! Interface members are implicitly public.
Not implementing all methods: If interface has 3 methods, class MUST implement all 3! Missing even one = compiler error.
Using 'new' instead of 'implements': C# uses ':' for BOTH inheritance and interfaces. 'class C : IDrawable' implements the interface (colon, not 'implements' keyword).
